title: Year in Review (A Special Report)  ---  What Was -2-
text:
Xi Jinping claims his third term as China's leader with his rivals out of the way, signaling greater state control over the world's No. 2 economy, after the U.S., and a more fraught relationship with the West

Oct. 25: New Leader in U.K.

U.K. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak pledges to repair the damage caused by the tax policies of his predecessor, Liz Truss, in her brief tenure

Oct. 27: Musk Buys Twitter

Elon Musk closes his on-again, off-again purchase of Twitter and fires the company's top executives

Oct. 27: GDP Turns Up

The U.S. economy grew in the third quarter after two negative quarters, but still showed signs of a broad slowdown, Commerce Department data shows

Oct. 27: Meta Stock Plunges

Facebook parent Meta Platforms loses nearly a quarter of its market value after posting a second consecutive revenue drop and growing metaverse losses; the stock has fallen more than 70% year to date

Oct. 28: Tech Crunch

A round of weak earnings reports marks an end to the tech boom, and Meta Platforms, Amazon and other companies will soon announce big layoffs

Oct. 29: South Korea Tragedy

More than 150 people have died from a crowd crush in one of Seoul's popular nightlife districts, following a massive turnout there for the Halloween weekend

Nov. 6: Capital Dries Up

The Fed's rate increases have sucked capital out of the markets, with mergers and stock and bond offerings slowing in October to the lowest level in over a decade, a Journal analysis shows

Nov. 8: Midterm Votes

In the midterm elections, Republicans will narrowly gain control of the House while Democrats will hold the Senate

Nov. 11: Ukraine Reclaims Kherson

Ukraine's forces sweep into the key southern city of Kherson in one of the biggest defeats for Russia in the war

Nov. 11: Crypto Collapse

Cryptocurrency exchange FTX files for bankruptcy protection -- a swift demise for a company seen as a trusted platform just a week earlier

Nov. 18: Special Counsel for Trump Probes

Attorney General Merrick Garland appoints a special counsel to oversee investigations into former President Trump's handling of documents at Mar-a-Lago and efforts to overturn the 2020 election results

Nov. 20: Disney Brings Back Iger

Following weak earnings and investor pressure, Walt Disney's board replaces CEO Bob Chapek with former CEO Robert Iger

Nov. 22: Missing Assets at FTX

A substantial amount of FTX's assets are missing or stolen, a lawyer for the failed crypto exchange says in court

Dec. 2: Price Cap on Russian Oil

The G-7 nations set a price cap of $60 a barrel on Russian oil, an unprecedented sanction on one of the world's largest oil producers

Dec. 6: Trump Organization Guilty of Tax Fraud

Former President Trump's family business is convicted of tax fraud for an off-the-books compensation schemeto pay some executives in car leases, apartments and cash

Dec. 7: China Retreats on Covid Policy

China drops most Covid testing and quarantine requirements, a hasty shift from its zero-Covid pandemic regime after nationwide protests and new economic disruptions

Dec. 13: FTX Founder Is Charged

FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried is charged by U.S. prosecutors with fraud and conspiracy, a day after he was arrested in the Bahamas

Dec. 13: Inflation Eases

Consumer prices rose 7.1% in November from a year earlier, the slowest pace since December 2021, the Labor Department says

Dec. 14: Fed Rate Rise

The Federal Reserve raises rates a half-point, less than 0.75 point for recent increases, but raises its estimate of how high rates will go in this tightening cycle
